media_caption: Nichols Field, site of first broadcasting experiments, 1941
text_description: The first known radio broadcast experiment in the Philippines is conducted by a Mrs Redgrave at Nichols Air Base. (Photo from US Air Force)

media_caption: KZKZ studio
text_description: Henry Herman begins test broadcasts from three stations, which are later consolidated into KZKZ under the Radio Corporation of the Philippines. Photo: KZKZ studio (Elizabeth Enriquez Collection)

media_caption: KZRC station housed in the Gotiaoco Building (later Heacock Building) in Cebu City, 1940
text_description: KZRC airs in Cebu, the first outside Manila. Photo: KZRC station housed in the Gotiaoco Building (later Heacock Building) in Cebu City, 1940 (Digital Tourism, gld.me)

media_caption: Joaquin Miguel Elizalde, one of the founders of the Manila Broadcasting Company
text_description: A new KZRH is back on the air under Joaquin (in photo) and Manuel Elizalde’s Manila Broadcasting Company. (Photo from Lou Gopal, Nostalgia Manila).

media_caption: Ric Manrique singing with Armida Siguion-Reyna in an episode of Aawitan Kita
text_description: Aawitan Kita, a weekly musical TV show hosted and produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna, begins airing on KBS Channel 9. It airs for 36 years on different channels. (Photo from NCCA)

media_caption: Crowd in panic during the Plaza Miranda bombing, Manila, 21 Aug 1971
text_description: ABS-CBN Channel 2 covers the bombing of the Liberal Party proclamation rally at Plaza Miranda. (Photo from Gerry Roxas Foundation)

Pres Ferdinand Marcos announces the declaration of martial law at 7:15 pm on KBS Channel 9 and DZRP. He padlocks broadcast stations and newspaper operations, except the Benedicto-owned KBS, Philippine Daily Express, and DZRP.

media_caption: Scene from the film adaptation of Edong Mapangarap, 1950, with screenplay by Virgilio “Beer” Flores
text_description: First radio stations go on air in Manila with radio serials by Lina Flor, Genoveva Edroza-Matute, Liwayway Arceo, and Horacio de la Costa. Later, many radio programs are made into films, like Edong Mapangarap (in photo), Prinsipe Amante, and Gulong ng Palad. (Photo from Video 48)

media_caption: KZIB broadcasting staff, 1938
text_description: Nov 9: Isaac Beck puts up KZIB. Photo: KZIB broadcasting staff, 1938 (National Economic Protectionism Association)

media_caption: Atang de la Rama
text_description: At the same time, Filipino music gains renewed popularity as artists like Atang de la Rama sing the kundiman on the air. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Rajio Taiso, a 15-minute calisthenics program aired over Japanese-controlled radio
text_description: Oct: Rajio Taiso, a daily calisthenics program, starts airing. All government employees and schoolchildren are required to follow. (Photo from Shin Seiki)

media_caption: Pres Manuel Roxas speaking on live broadcast during the declaration of Philippine Independence, 1946, as Vice Pres Elpidio Quirino, seated at left, looks on
media_credit: Photo from Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines
text_description: KZFM, KZRH, and KZPI cover the declaration of Philippine independence and the inauguration of Pres Roxas. (Photo from Presidential Museum and Library of the Philippines)

media_caption: KZRH first aired from the Heacock’s Department Store on Escolta, Binondo, Manila before World War II
text_description: Jul 14: H. E. Heacock Co. opens KZRH. Photo: KZRH first aired from the Heacock’s Department Store on Escolta, Binondo, Manila before World War II (Photo from Lou Gopal/Nostalgia Manila)

media_caption: Judge Antonio Quirino, founder of DZAQ-TV
text_description: Judge Antonio Quirino (in photo), brother of Pres Elpidio Quirino, buys the controlling shares of Bolinao Electronics Company and re-names it Alto Broadcasting System (ABS). It will be used for the latter’s re-election campaign. (Photo from ABS-CBN)

media_caption: ABS building on Dewey Boulevard, Pasay City, 1960
text_description: Eugenio Lopez Sr buys ABS from Antonio Quirino and James Lindenberg. Photo: ABS building on Dewey Boulevard, Pasay City, 1960 (ABS-CBN)
The Roces family, publisher of the newspaper The Manila Times, establishes the television station DZMT Channel 5 under the Associated Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).

media_caption: Manila Broadcasting Company logo, 1970-1971
text_description: MBC-TV Channel 11 goes on the air with the first TV news program in Tagalog, Ano ang Balita. (Photo from MBC)

Jul: DZXL’s CBN Canteen, a 15-minute lunchtime musical program, debuts. When featured singer Priscilla Aristorenas moves to London, the program is reformatted as a talk-music show with Leila Benitez as host.

media_caption: Print advertisement of Salamisim, ca 1968
text_description: The drama anthology Salamisim airs on ABC 5. (Photo from Simon Santos/Video 48)

media_caption: Gabriel “Flash” Elorde and Harold Gomes during their historic fight, 1960
text_description: The World Lightweight Boxing Championship match between Gabriel “Flash” Elorde and Harold Gomes is aired on Channel 3. Elorde wins the title. (Photo from Elorde Gilmore Boxing Gym)

media_caption: Rafael Yabut, host of Tayo’y Mag-aliw
text_description: Rafael “Paeng” Yabut inserts his stinging news commentary in the music program Tayo’y Mag-aliw and begins the tradition of fiery social and political criticism on the air. (Photo from Alex R. Castro)

media_caption: Dong Puno Live
text_description: The current affairs debate show Dong Puno Live, later Dong Puno Tonight, airs on ABS-CBN 2. (Screenshot from Arturo Paguntalan/Youtube)

media_caption: Benigno Aquino, left, on Face the Nation, with host Ronnie Nathanielsz, 10 Mar 1978
text_description: Journalists interview Aquino live from Fort Bonifacio on the talk show Face the Nation on GTV 4. (Photo from Ninoy and Cory Foundation)

media_caption: Miss Universe 1974 contestants watching a parade at the Quirino Grandstand
text_description: Jul 19: RPN 9 airs the 23rd Miss Universe pageant held at the Folk Arts Theater in Manila, with simultaneous international broadcasts. (Photo from Carl Kuntze)

media_caption: 9TV and CNN anchors and executives during the CNN Philippines launch, 2014
text_description: CNN Philippines airs on Channel 9 under license by Turner Broadcasting System. (Photo from Rappler)

media_caption: Original MYX VJs Iya Villania, left, Luis Manzano, and Nikki Gil at the MYX MO! Festival, 2008
text_description: ABS-CBN establishes MYX, the first Filipino 24/7 music channel, on SKYcable. (Photo by Noel Orsal)

media_caption: Pioneering Probe hosts and producers Luchi Cruz-Valdes, left, Maria Ressa, and Cheche Lazaro, 2009
text_description: Probe pioneers investigative broadcast journalism in the country and airs on ABS-CBN. Photo: Pioneering Probe hosts and producers Luchi Cruz-Valdes, left, Maria Ressa, and Cheche Lazaro, 2009 (Ella Marie Evangelista-Martelino)

media_caption: Scene from Ditsi Carolino’s Minsan Lang Sila Bata, 1996
media_credit: Photo from Ateneo Center for Social Policy
text_description: Minsan Lang Sila Bata, a documentary on child labor, airs on GMA 7. (Photo from Ateneo Center for Social Policy)

media_caption: Hamon ng Kalikasan: Climate Change advertisement, 2012
text_description: GMA7's Hamon ng Kalikasan goes on the air as the first meteorology program in the Philippines. (Photo from GMA Network)

media_caption: Agot Isidro in a scene from Titser, 2013
text_description: The drama Titser, which examines the state of public education in the Philippines, airs on GMA News TV Channel 11. (Photo from GMA Network)

media_caption: Original cast members of Batibot, from left, Junix Inocian, Sienna Olaso, and at right, Bodjie Pascua, joined by puppets Kiko Matsing and Pong Pagong
text_description: The longest running children’s show Batibot airs on RPN 9. (Photo from Philippine Children’s Television Foundation)

media_caption: Charo Santos, host of Maalaala Mo Kaya, 2016
text_description: The drama anthology of true-to-life stories Maala-ala Mo Kaya, airs on ABS-CBN. Photo: Charo Santos, host of Maalaala Mo Kaya, 2016 (ABS-CBN)

media_caption: Dennis Trillo, Carla Abellana, and Tom Rodriguez in a web advertisement of My Husband’s Lover, 2013
text_description: My Husband's Lover, a telenovela on gay characters and dilemmas, airs on GMA7. (Photo from GMA Network))

media_caption: Scene from Sineskwela, 1994
text_description: The curriculum-based educational program Sineskwela airs on ABS-CBN, the Knowledge Channel, and The Filipino Channel. (Photo from ABS-CBN)

media_caption: Angelo Cometa, left, and Agatha Tapan in the “Jose Rizal: Sa Aking Mga Kababata” episode of Bayani, 1995
text_description: The history program Bayani begins its six-year run on ABS-CBN. (Photo from ABS-CBN)

media_caption: Sharlene San Pedro in an episode of Wansapanataym, 2014
text_description: The children's fantasy series Wansapanataym airs on ABS-CBN. (Photo from ABS-CBN)

media_caption: Hardcourt idols Alberto Guidaben and Robert Jaworski, 1975
text_description: BBC 2 begins live coverage of the Philippine Basketball Association (PBA) games. Photo: PBA idols Alberto Guidaben and Robert Jaworski, 1975 (Photo from Simon Santos/Video 48)

media_caption: Thrilla in Manila, the boxing match between Joe Frazier, left, and Muhammad Ali, with Filipino referee Carlos Padilla Jr, center, 1975
text_description: RPN 9 broadcasts live the boxing match between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier dubbed Thrilla in Manila at the Araneta Coliseum in Quezon City. (Photo from sportsblog.com)

media_caption: Nestor de Villa and Nida Blanca on The Nida-Nestor Show, 1965
media_credit: Photo from Pinoy Television: The Story of ABS-CBN, The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan, ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999
text_description: The musical-variety The Nida-Nestor Show airs on ABS-CBN Channel 3. (Photo from Pinoy Television: The Story of ABS-CBN, The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan, ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999)

media_caption: Dely Magpayo on the set of Mga Liham Kay Tiya Dely, 1958
text_description: Fidela Magpayo hosts a drama show with a new format, Kasaysayan sa mga Liham kay Tiya Dely, later renamed Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely on DZRH. (Photo from Didi Magpayo-Reyes)

media_caption: Cast of 5 and Up, 1992
media_credit: Photo from GMA Gold: 50 Years of Broadcast History, edited by Chelo Banal-Formoso, GMA Network, 2001
text_description: 5 and Up, a tele-magazine hosted by kids ages 8 to 14, premieres on ABC 5. Cast of 5 and Up, 1992 (GMA Gold: 50 Years of Broadcast History, edited by Chelo Banal-Formoso, GMA Network, 2001)

media_caption: Tessie Tomas and Noel Trinidad in Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata
text_description: Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata, a satirical sitcom, airs on ABS-CBN. Photo: Tessie Tomas and Noel Trinidad in Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata, 1991 (ABS-CBN)

media_caption: Pres. Ferdinand Marcos and his generals on national television during the 1986 EDSA Revolt
text_description: The documentary Batas Militar airs on ABS-CBN.

media_caption: Pempe Padilla, left, Rita Amor, Jaime de la Rosa, and Lucas Paredes in the “Gregorio del Pilar” episode of Camay Theater in the Air, 1949
media_credit: Photo from James de la Rosa/Baul ni Juan
text_description: Camay Theater of the Air airs on DZBC, then moves to DZBB. Photo: Pempe Padilla, left, Rita Amor, Jaime de la Rosa, and Lucas Paredes in the “Gregorio del Pilar” episode of Camay Theater in the Air, 1949 (James de la Rosa/Baul ni Juan)

media_caption: Scene from Chinatown TV, 2013
text_description: The magazine show Chinatown TV airs on IBC 13. (Photo from Chinatown TV)

media_caption: Gel Santos-Relos and Atty. Renato Cayetano, hosts of Compañero y Compañera, 1997
text_description: The legal talk show Compañero y Compañera airs on DZMM, then a TV version on ABS-CBN follows. Photo: Gel Santos-Relos and Atty. Renato Cayetano, hosts of Compañero y Compañera, 1997 (ABS-CBN)
Concert at the Park airs on GTV4, with simulcast on DZRB.

media_caption: Pilita Corrales in An Evening with Pilita, 1964
media_credit: Photo from Pinoy Television: The Story of ABS-CBN, The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan, ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999
text_description: The musical-variety show An Evening with Pilita, the first to be videotaped, airs. (Photo from Pinoy Television: The Story of ABS-CBN, The Medium of Our Lives, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan, ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999)

media_caption: Print advertisement for Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato, 1962
text_description: Considered the first soap opera on Philippine TV, Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato airs on ABS-CBN 3. (Photo from Simon Santos/Video 48)

media_caption: Kuh Ledesma, 2012
text_description: The musical Kuh by Special Arrangement featuring Filipino popular music airs on IBC 13. Photo: Kuh Ledesma, 2012 (Photo from Kuh Ledesma)

media_caption: Program logo for Mindalinaw, 2004
text_description: The talk show Mindalinaw, about people caught in conflicts in Mindanao, airs on DZMS, DZMY, and DXGO. (Photo from DXGO)

media_caption: Scene from the television adaptation of Noli Me Tangere, 1992, featuring Bodjie Pascua, left, Joel Torre, Ruben Rustia, and Cezar Xerez-Burgos, among others.
text_description: The CCP produces several programs, including Pinoy Eh, a television magazine show on Filipino art and culture, and the 13-episode television drama series Noli Me Tangere (in photo) based on Jose Rizal's novel. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Out! hosts JM Cobarrubias, Avi Siwa, and Jigs Mayuga
text_description: The first LGBTQ talk show in Southeast Asia, Out! airs on GMA 7. Photo: Out! hosts JM Cobarrubias, Avi Siwa, and Jigs Mayuga (GMA Network)

media_caption: The Singing Brawners in an episode of Paco Park Presents, 2001
text_description: Paco Park Presents, a program of classical music, begins its 32-year run on MBS 4. Photo: The Singing Brawners in an episode of Paco Park Presents, 2001 (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Richard Gutierrez, host of Planet Philippines, 2009
text_description: Planet Philippines, a documentary about the environment, airs on GMA7. (Photo from GMA Network)

media_caption: Inside the radio booth during an episode of Pugasan sa Kahanginan, 2014
media_credit: Photo from Central Visayas Farmers Development Center, Inc
text_description: Pugasan sa Kahanginan, a talk show for farmers in Bohol, Cebu and Negros Oriental, airs on DYHP. (Photo from Central Visayas Farmers Development Center, Inc)

media_caption: Chichay and Tolindoy in a promotional photo of Purico Troubadours, 1940s
text_description: Purico Troubadours, a daily variety show, begins airing on KZRH. Photo: Chichay and Tolindoy in a promotional photo of Purico Troubadours (Elizabeth Enriquez)

media_caption: Poster for the film adaptation of Recuerdo, 1953
text_description: Based on a komiks serial, the soap Recuerdo, written by Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, airs on DZPI. Photo: Poster for the film adaptation of Recuerdo, 1953 (Photo from Simon Santos/Video 48)

media_caption: An episode of Sugpuin ang Korupsyon, aka DiskArte, 2014, with hosts Henry Uri, left, and Flor Abanto, right, and guest Eva Mari Salvador, middle
text_description: The CCP produces award-winning Diskarte, formerly titled Sugpuin ang Korupsyon, on DZRH. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: Womanwatch host Nikki Coseteng, 2016
text_description: Radyo Womanwatch produced by activist women belonging to Women in Media Now airs on DZSR. The following year, Womanwatch airs on Channel 4. Photo: Womanwatch host Nikki Coseteng, 2016 (Photo from Anna Dominique Coseteng)

media_caption: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card, signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930
text_description: Radio Corporation of the Philippines opens KZRM and puts KZKZ off the air. (Photo from Amateur Radio Station)

media_caption: Young Ramon Jacinto, founder of DZRJ
text_description: Ramon Jacinto begins operating DZRJ under the Rajah Broadcasting Network. (Photo from Ramon Jacinto)

media_caption: Facade and reflecting pool of the Cultural Center of the Philippines
media_credit: Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites. John Weatherhill Inc, 1977.
text_description: Pres Ferdinand Marcos inaugurates the Cultural Center of the Philippines as a venue for the performing arts. (Photo by Akio Kawasumi in The Architecture of Leandro V. Locsin by Nicholas Polites, John Weatherhill Inc, 1977)

media_caption: Nora Aunor dancing on Superstar
text_description: The musical variety program Superstar, hosted by Nora Aunor, begins its 18-year run on Channel 9. (Photo from Nestor de Guzman)

media_caption: Orly Mercado, Cielito del Mundo, and Dr Antonio Talusan, hosts of Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko, 1976
media_credit: Photo from Photo from Kapwa Ko Mahal Ko, www.kapwako.org
text_description: The GMA Channel 7 program Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko features volunteer sign language interpreters, the first program to do so.(Photo from Kapwa Ko Mahal Ko, www.kapwako.org)
Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko

media_caption: Funeral procession of Benigno Aquino Jr along Rizal Park, Manila, 1983
text_description: DZRV and other radio stations cover Aquino’s 12-hour funeral procession from the Santo Domingo Church in Quezon City to the Manila Memorial Park in Parañaque, but their signals are jammed. GMA 7 devotes eight seconds during its primetime news to the funeral. (Photo by Joe Arazas)

media_caption: Trophy designed by Julie Lluch for the first Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon.
text_description: The CCP launches the annual Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon. Photo: Trophy designed by Julie Lluch for the first Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon. (CCP Collection)

media_caption: Culture Carousel host and producer Irene Obligacion-Rada interviewing double bassist Kurt Muroki, 2012
text_description: The weekly radio program Culture Carousel airs on DZFE. (Photo from CCP)

media_caption: MTRCB Logo
text_description: The MTRCB applies the classifications G (General Patronage), PG (Patnubay at Gabay, or Parental Guidance), and X (Disapproved for Airing) to television programs. (Photo from MTRCB)
The Elizalde brothers (Federico, Joaquin Miguel, and Manuel) establish DZRH-TV Channel 11.
